ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned more Japanese grammar and vocabulary. I also practiced speaking and writing Japanese essays.
Rudimentary Japanese speaking, reading, and listening skills.
I developed the ability to memorize language skills and techniques
We went more in-depth into Japanese vocabulary, grammar, and culture, and developed more speaking and writing skills.
L2 Japanese skills including: conversational ability, kanji, vocabulary
Japanese grammar, vocab, etc.
Speaking, reading and writing in Japanese. Around 100 Kanji beyond L1 and various grammatical forms. Especially significant was the casual form which greatly expanded speaking ability
We learned over 100 kanji, a continuation of Japanese grammar, conversational Japanese, and listening comprehension.

Reading, writing, and speaking about topics like cooking, studying abroad, and the weather in Japanese, along with grammar such as casual form, expressing opinions, and noun modifiers, and about 90 more Kanji.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is fast paced, but you learn a lot of Japanese. It is very organized.

I cannot think of a real "weakness" of the course. Class was engaging as long as you attended them live and participated in class activities, and there weren't problems with test administration. Homework was made very clear using the modules system in canvas.
Really fast-paced and difficult to keep up with. Though it is a lot of work, it really does push you to learn the language.
Great class! Learned so much and can read/say more in Japanese now. Very high learning curve but the grammar does get harder in L2
Well structured, could be good to have a formal introduction of vocabulary words at the start of each chapter rather than just self-study.

The strengths of this class was the definitely the way that it was taught (all of the students were very engaged and the environment was always very amicable and conducive to learning). There is no way that I think this course could be improved.

The course was well organized with homework and assessments laid out in weekly schedules. The lectures usually have conversation sessions to practice speaking with classmates, which makes the course more engaging and also helps you connect with your classmates better. Since lessons 11 and 12 are in a new textbook with more vocabularies and longer conversations, certain vocabularies are practiced less during lectures and clinic sessions, making them harder to memorize and use well.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the breakout rooms to practice speaking Japanese with my peers, but sometimes it was difficult to hear students who were in the classroom (a lot of background noise). However, I understand that is something a bit unavoidable.

Usage of breakout rooms was effective in still allowing students to talk to each other as if they were in a classroom. Usage of the modules system on Canvas made homework easily accessible and assignment due dates easily understandable.

Having our mics unmuted the entire time because truthfully there was one student (who I am pretty sure is somewhat knowledgeable about Chinese language(s) which holds similarity to Japanese) and he often made it his role to speak over everyone. In those moments, I couldn't even hear myself speak, and I felt like I was missing out on learning opportunities.

This was the only in-person class I had and it worked very well. It was a huge relief to have some normalcy in this semester and helped me mentally and academically throughout. Also got to know people in the class and engage better.

I think that having the in-person option was very helpful to create a community atmosphere in the class and both the in-person and remote students were able to seamlessly switch in and out of breakout rooms and converse with each other.

The live lectures were well organized, and I didn't feel like it is worse than the in-person lectures. The breakout rooms in Zoom worked really well for conversation sessions, although we do have some technical problems every so often, it does not significantly impact learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. If you wish to learn Japanese, this is really the only way at Yale, and Stever-sensei was great at explaining things to people who had no exposure to Japanese.

Without prior experience, I would not recommend this course to other students because it isn't advantageous, considering you will have three other courses. The only way to really get a good grade AND learn the language will be to prioritize this class over other classes, which I don't think is fair to any student or other professors.

I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to continue learning Japanese. Although a lot of material is covered in a short span of time, the daily practice really helps to reinforce the grammar and vocabulary (and is really engaging).
Yes, Stever sensei is wonderful and understanding and she makes the class so fun! It's a great course if you want to learn Japanese and make friends who also like Japanese.

Yes, it's a great continuation to L1 and you will find yourself actually being able to speak and string together decently complicated ideas. Stever-sensei is absolutely amazing as well and really patient and will teach you a lot.
Yes, I think that the way that Stever-sensei was able to teach the students in such an engaging manner was truly wonderful and I would recommend it to other students.
Yes, if you would like to learn more about Japanese and Japanese culture.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Some people on campus could go to the classroom, though I was online the whole semester.
N/A
We also had virtual clinics that met for one hour per week in addition to daily class.
live virtual lecture

In person class was available for people on campus who was comfortable with/ wanted to attend but the class was also half over zoom. Basically, a few of us would be in a classroom but also logged on to zoom.
Hybrid seminar with four of us attending in-person and seven online. Once weekly online live language clinic session with an undergrad TF and another student in L2.
There was the option for in person classes if the students were on campus and the rest was taught virtually with an integration of the in-person students and the remote students
